newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: APEC to calculate impact of trade liberalisation.
newsitem.headline: APEC to calculate impact of trade liberalisation.

text.p: The Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum plans to quantify the gains and losses of its regional trade liberalisation plan, a Japanese delegate said on Friday.

"We will work on the measures and make a calculation on what the impacts these measures will have on the economies of the APEC region," Kazutomo Abe, head of an APEC task force studying impact of trade liberalisation, told reporters.
The trade liberalisation programme, which is one of the cornerstones of the 18-member group, aims to bring down tariffs to zero by 2010 for developed countries and 2020 for developing countries.
Abe said the exercise would identify which sectors of each economy would gain or lose by a tariff reduction programme.
Other studies by multilateral agencies have shown that overall, economies tend to benefit from a free-trade regime, he said.
"(The studies) generally indicate that the trade liberalisation measures will benefit all areas in terms of increasing GDP (gross domestic product) and increasing trade," Abe added.
These economic gains could easily offset any negative impacts, he said.
Some developing countries have expressed fears that freer trade could stifle infant industries.

APEC is comprised of Australia, Brunei, Canada, Chile, China, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Japan, South Korea, Malaysia, Mexico, New Zealand, Papua New Guinea, Philippines, Singapore, Taiwan, Thailand and the United States.
